title: Ticket #4654: Non-awful hold messages for VM Universe
description:
The HoldReason for VM universe jobs which failed to launch is pretty terrible. A rough draft of suggestions follows. One possibility for implementation is to use the param table infrastructure to create an "error table" or "hold reason table" in which condor_q will look the short-form hold reasons to print out the long-form hold reasons below. Similar code would be welcomed / required for the (user) job log.

(The instructions for VMGAHP_ERR_JOBCLASSAD_NO_VMWARE_VMX_PARAM are a little different than the others; it's not clear if it's better or not.) 

VMGAHP_ERR_JOBCLASSAD_NO_VM_MEMORY_PARAM

    The attribute ${ATTR_JOB_VM_MEMORY} was not set in the job ad sent to the
VM GAHP.  HTCondor will usually prevent you from submitting a VM universe job
without ${ATTR_JOB_VM_MEMORY} set, so this may not be your fault.  Examine
your job (condor_q -l $(CLUSTER_ID).$(PROC_ID)) and verify that ${ATTR_JOB_VM_MEMORY}
is set.  If it is, please contact your administrator.

VMGAHP_ERR_JOBCLASSAD_NO_VMWARE_VMX_PARAM

    The attribute ${VMPARAM_VMWARE_DIR} was not set in the job ad sent to the
VM GAHP.  HTCondor will usually set this attribute when you submit a valid
VMWare job (it is derived from vmware_dir).  If you used condor_submit to
submit this job, contact your administrator.  Otherwise, examine your job
(condor_q -l $(CLUSTER_ID).$(PROC_ID)) and verify that ${VMPARAM_VMWARE_DIR}
is set.  If it is, contact your administrator.

VMGAHP_ERR_JOBCLASSAD_KVM_NO_DISK_PARAM

    The attribute ${VMPARAM_VM_DISK} was not set in the job ad sent to the
VM GAHP.  HTCondor will usually prevent you from submitting a KVM job without
${VMPARAM_VM_DISK} being set, so this may not be your fault.  Examine
your job (condor_q -l $(CLUSTER_ID).$(PROC_ID)) and verify that ${VMWARE_VM_DISK}
is set.  If it is, please contact your administrator.

VMGAHP_ERR_JOBCLASSAD_KVM_INVALID_DISK_PARAM

    The attribute ${VMPARAM_VM_DISK} was invalid.  Please consult the manual,
or the condor_submit man page, for information about the syntax of ${VMPARAM_VM_DISK}
A syntactically correct value may be invalid if the on-disk permissions
of a file specified in it do not match the requested permissions.  Presently,
files not transferred to the root of the working directory must be specified
with full paths.

VMGAHP_ERR_JOBCLASSAD_KVM_MISMATCHED_CHECKPOINT

    KVM jobs can not presently checkpoint if any of their disk files are not
on a shared filesystem.  Files on a shared filesystem must be specified in
${VMPARAM_VM_DISK} with full paths.

VMGAHP_ERR_JOBCLASSAD_XEN_NO_KERNEL_PARAM

    The attribute ${VMPARAM_XEN_KERNEL} was not set in the job ad sent to the
VM GAHP.  HTCondor will usually prevent you from submitting a Xen job without
${VMPARAM_XEN_KERNEL} being set, so this may not be your fault.  Examine
your job (condor_q -l $(CLUSTER_ID).$(PROC_ID)) and verify that ${VMPARAM_XEN_KERNEL}
is set.  If it is, please contact your administrator.

VMGAHP_ERR_JOBCLASSAD_MISMATCHED_HARDWARE_VT

    Don't use 'vmx' as the name of your kernel image.  Pick something else and
change ${VMPARAM_XEN_KERNEL} to match.

VMGAHP_ERR_JOBCLASSAD_XEN_KERNEL_NOT_FOUND

    HTCondor could not read from the file specified by ${VMPARAM_XEN_KERNEL}.
Check the path and the file's permissions.  If it's on a shared filesystem,
you may need to alter your job's requirements expression to ensure the
filesystem's availability.

VMGAHP_ERR_JOBCLASSAD_XEN_INITRD_NOT_FOUND

    HTCondor could not read from the file specified by ${VMPARAM_XEN_INITRD}.
Check the path and the file's permissions.  If it's on a shared filesystem,
you may need to alter your job's requirements expression to ensure the
filesystem's availability.

VMGAHP_ERR_JOBCLASSAD_XEN_NO_ROOT_DEVICE_PARAM

    The attribute ${VMPARAM_XEN_ROOT} was not set in the job ad sent to the
VM GAHP.  HTCondor will usually prevent you from submitting a Xen job without
${VMPARAM_XEN_ROOT} being set, so this may not be your fault.  Examine
your job (condor_q -l $(CLUSTER_ID).$(PROC_ID)) and verify that ${VMWARE_XEN_ROOT}
is set.  If it is, please contact your administrator.

VMGAHP_ERR_JOBCLASSAD_XEN_NO_DISK_PARAM

    The attribute ${VMPARAM_VM_DISK} was not set in the job ad sent to the
VM GAHP.  HTCondor will usually prevent you from submitting a Xen job without
${VMPARAM_VM_DISK} being set, so this may not be your fault.  Examine
your job (condor_q -l $(CLUSTER_ID).$(PROC_ID)) and verify that ${VMWARE_VM_DISK}
is set.  If it is, please contact your administrator.

VMGAHP_ERR_JOBCLASSAD_XEN_INVALID_DISK_PARAM

    The attribute ${VMPARAM_VM_DISK} was invalid.  Please consult the manual,
or the condor_submit man page, for information about the syntax of ${VMPARAM_VM_DISK}
A syntaxically-correct value may be also be invalid if the on-disk permissions
of a file specified in it do not match the requested permissions.  Presently,
files not transferred to the root of the working directory must be specified
with full paths.

VMGAHP_ERR_JOBCLASSAD_XEN_MISMATCHED_CHECKPOINT

    Xen jobs can not presently checkpoint if any of their disk files are not
on a shared filesystem.  Files on a shared filesystem must be specified in
${VMPARAM_VM_DISK} with full paths.
remarks:
2015-Jan-06 12:14:14 by bbockelm:
Hold up on this one -- I'm not entirely sure about the approach here.

If I understand right the approach here is, condor_q itself does some simple string matching on hold reason and substitutes strings from a lookup table.

I worry about this because:

  • This means that different condor CLI versions would have different outputs for "condor_q -held"
  • Different clients (HTCondor-C, python bindings) would get different versions of the hold message.
  • "condor_q -af:h ClusterID HoldReason" would have different hold reasons than "condor_q -held"
  • I worry about using string mangling for the substitution (seems brittle) instead of hold sub-codes.

You start to get inconsistencies between CLI output and the contents of the classad, which results in things like #4808 which look like a scary maintenance nightmare to me.

As string constants are collapsed into a single object by ClassAds, the memory savings of having shorter strings in the schedd are going to be miniscule. On first blush, this approach seems to be problematic versus having the startd set a more reasonable hold reason in the first place.

Is there a design doc here? Who did the code review? I think this warrants further attention, or at least recording previous discussions onto the ticket...

2015-Jan-06 14:02:35 by tlmiller:
(Made verbatim to make the quotes readable on the web.) 
> This means that different condor CLI versions would have different outputs
> for "condor_q -held"

Why is that a problem?  I don't think we make any promises about output
stability.  What would be better?  A new flag to condor_q that nobody knows
about?  Printing the explanations beneath the output?

> Different clients (HTCondor-C, python bindings) would get different versions
> of the hold message.

The hold message is the one in the job ad; everybody /except/ condor_q -hold
sees the same message.

> "condor_q -af:h ClusterID HoldReason" would have different hold reasons than
> "condor_q -held"

This is entirely deliberate; I'm assuming that 'condor_q -hold' is used
primarily by users (rather than scripts).

> I worry about using string mangling for the substitution (seems brittle)
> instead of hold sub-codes.

This is true.  I suppose hold reason codes and sub-codes are cheap enough to
add to the projection.

> You start to get inconsistencies between CLI output and the contents of the
> classad, which results in things like #4808 which look like a scary
> maintenance nightmare to me.

Again, this is entirely deliberate -- we want to give the user more information.

> As string constants are collapsed into a single object by ClassAds, the
> memory savings of having shorter strings in the schedd are going to be
> miniscule. On first blush, this approach seems to be problematic versus
> having the startd set a more reasonable hold reason in the first place.

My original plan was, indeed, to just set a longer hold reason.  That got shot
down by ToddT and TJ; I'm not sure why.  (Perhaps because the strings aren't
compressed over the wire?)

> Is there a design doc here?

No.

> Who did the code review?

For a feature commit to the devel branch?

> I think this warrants further attention, or at least recording previous
> discussions onto the ticket...

Fair enough.

2015-Apr-22 15:23:40 by bbockelm:
From the OSG/HTCondor call:

Is it possible to (cheaply) revise this patch to change the hold message on the server side (Brian has strongest preference to not do this in condor_q)? Preference would be to get it done in the 8.3 series.

2015-Apr-22 16:12:36 by cat:
Todd Miller claims that Todd Tannenbaum objected to long messages going over the wire, hence the client-side solution (which in turn may have its own issues). I propose that either (a) ToddM, ToddT, and BrianB meet to hash out an acceptable solution, or if need be (b) the messages be made short on the server side and clearly point users to a look-up table in the documentation.

2015-May-06 15:17:39 by bbockelm:
Update: this got priority bumped; likely won't make 8.3.6.
